title: Geometric Abstraction
marks: Signature and Edition LRC, in black: [Sonia Delaunay / 7/900]
text: Sonia Delaunay-Terk, often collaborated with her husband Robert Delaunay, whose painting <I>St. Severin <I> (1909) is currently on view in G371. <I>Geometric Abstraction<I> still uses the concept of <I>simultan√©isme<I>, but instead of using lines, as seen in the fabric <I>Ulysee<I> seen nearby, Delaunay-Terk dominated this textile with geometric shapes and colors which seem to infuse the piece with energetic movement. Here, the stronger contrasts of red, yellow, blue, and green dominate the diagonals of the panel, relieved by areas of gray and white squares, giving the illusion that this pattern could continue without end. An abstract yet still functional piece, <I>Geometric Abstraction<I> is similar to various designs Delaunay-Terk developed in the 1920s for avant-garde clothing.
description: overall pattern of various sized squares on light grey over cream:  red, green, yellow, dark grey, white
